question: Question_06_(a)
statement:
Determine the coeï¬cients \emph{c\textsubscript{n}} in the expansion

\[f(x) = \sum_{n = -\infty}^\infty c_n e^{2\pi inx}\] where \emph{$f$(x) =
x} and $0 \leq x \leq 1$.
sols:
We can get the coefficients using orthogonality. Take the inner product
with each $e_{n}(x)$

\[\langle e_{n},f \rangle = \sum_{i=-\infty}^{\infty} c_{i} \langle e_{n},e_{i} \rangle = c_{n} \langle e_{n},e_{n} \rangle =c_{n}L\]

\[c_{n} = \frac{1}{L} \int_{a}^{b} e^{-2\pi i\frac{nx}{L}}f(x)dx\]

Since \emph{L = b-a} and \emph{b=1} and \emph{a=0},

\[c_{n} = \int_{0}^{1} e^{-2\pi inx}f(x)dx\]

If \emph{n = 0},

\[c_{0} = \int_{0}^{1} f(x)dx = \left [\frac{1}{2}x^{2} \right ]^{1}_{0}= \frac{1}{2}\]

If $n\neq 0,$ we use integration by parts\[\int udv=uv-\int vdu\] with
$u = x$, $dv = e^{-2\pi inx}dx$ to obtain

\begin{align*}
c_{n} &= \left [\frac{x}{-2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} + \int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx}dx \\
&= \left [-\frac{x}{2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx} - \frac{1}{4\pi^{2} i^{2}n^{2}} e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} \\
&= \left [-\frac{x}{2\pi in} e^{-2\pi inx} + \frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}} e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} \\
&= \left [\left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{x}{2\pi in} \right) e^{-2\pi inx} \right ]^{1}_{0} \\
&= \left [\left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right) e^{-2\pi in(1)} \right ]-\left [\left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-0 \right) e^{-2\pi in(0)} \right ] \\
&= \left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right) e^{-2\pi in}- \frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}} \\
&= \left(\frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}}-\frac{1}{2\pi in} \right) (1)- \frac{1}{4\pi^{2}n^{2}} \\
&=-\frac{1}{2\pi in}
\end{align*}
